 Page 2 Introduction Maternal and Child Health 1.5 The declines in life expectancy also reflect a worsening in infant mortality. Infant mortality, which dropped from 22.0 per 1,000 live births in 1980 to 17.4 in 1990, rose to 19.9 in 1993, before declining to 18.6 in 1994. This rate is two to three times as high as in OECD countries. Maternal mortality, at 52 per 100,000 live births (1993), is five to ten times as high as in other industrialized countries. The main causes are complications from abortions, post-partum bleeding and toxemia. Contraceptive prevalence is low. The official rate for modern methods was 22.8 percent in 1993. Although rates of over 40 percent have been reported, these include a high proportion, perhaps as much as half, of non-modern methods (e.g., rhythm, withdrawal). This low rate of contraceptive use is compensated for by reliance on abortion; in Russia, there are more than two abortions per live birth. Maternal health is further complicated by high rates of anemia. 1.6 Children also suffer from anemia. A recent survey found the prevalence of anemia for children under age two at between 10 and 15 percent in major cities and at about 25 percent in the surrounding oblasts. Immunization rates ranging from 60 to 80 percent are fairly comparable to those in other industrialized countries. The availability of vaccines is not a major problem in Russia, as, in the past, Russia was the main source of vaccines for all of the USSR. Children who survive to their first birthday are likely to reach adulthood, but then have a one in four chance of dying before age 60. Demographic Crisis 1.7 The convergence of increased mortality and declining birth rates since 1988 has led to what Russian health officials speak of as the "demographic crisis." In fact, this issue is highlighted as the most significant concern in the 1992 "State Report on the Status of Health of the Population in the Russian Federation" (1992 State Report).  Introduction Page 3 1.9 Smoking is very prevalent in Russia, with approximately 60 percent of adult men and 15 percent of adult women smoking. The difference in smoking prevalence is a major factor contributing to the gender patterns in morbidity and mortality. While male smoking trends have remained stable at fairly high levels, the prevalence of smoking among women, particularly young women, is increasing and will undoubtedly be reflected in health status in the future. 1.10 Household surveys reveal a marked change in diet between 1989 and 1992, including significant decreases in the consumption of fruits and vegetables, fish, meat and milk and dairy products, and sharp increases in the consumption of bread and potatoes. These changes were, in part, beneficial. Prior to 1989, fat consumption was 10 to 15 percent higher than the recommended levels, while by 1992 calories from fat represented 31 percent of daily caloric intake, although a high proportion still comes from animal fats. Undernutrition is not a significant problem; however, the prevalence of obesity is high, particularly among women, and contributes to the high incidence of cardiovascular disease. 1.11 Adult morbidity and mortality are adversely affected by unhealthful and often dangerous working conditions. Industrial pollution is also a significant problem, leading to regional variations in respiratory diseases and various forms of cancer, although hard data linking causes and effects are not readily available. Similarly, high levels of radiation resulting from nuclear accidents require long-term epidemiological monitoring. B. ORGANIZATION OF HEALTH SERVICES 1.12 The Russian health care system as it now exists reflects both the positive and negative attributes of the Soviet system from which it evolved. On the positive side, access is universal and the system is extensive. On the negative side, the system is not sufficiently funded to support the comprehensive service it attempts to provide, and the quality of care suffers as a consequence. Furthermore, the theoretical universality of access is seriously compromised, with marked inequities in real access, particularly to better quality or highly-specialized services, among regions and among various social and economic groups. 1.13 The public health system in Russia comprises 12,000 hospitals and maternity homes (2.8 million beds), 15,500 polyclinics and women's consultations, and 3,500 ambulatories. There are 48 medical academies, 117 research institutes and 34 major diagnostic centers. In parallel, some 600 hospitals and 1,700 outpatient clinics are operated under the auspices of the Ministries of Defense, Interior, and Railways and other ministries and agencies. Large enterprises may also operate their own health care facilities for the benefit of their employees and (sometimes) families and residents of the immediate community. Facilities in this "parallel system" are often superior to public facilities because they are better financed. 1.14 Since 1992, provision and financing (see next section) of health care have been decentralized to the oblasts1'. At the oblast level, a typical health care system would comprise a central oblast hospital (a tertiary-level general hospital with perhaps 1,000 beds, usually the best equipped, staffed and financed facility in the oblast), several specialty hospitals, e.g., pediatric, emergency, psychiatric, tuberculosis, I' Here and in the rest of this document, the term oblast is used interchangeably with the more accurate term for the second administrative level in the Federation: "subjects of the Federation" (i.e., Republics, krai, oblasts, and the cities of Moscow and St. Petersburg). The term "region" is also sometimes used to refer to this level. The rayon is the administrative level next down from the oblast.

 Introduction Page 5 C. HEALTH CARE AND MEDICAL PRACTICE 1.18 Health care in Russia is characterized by excessive reliance on curative and inpatient care. Although there is a strong tradition of preventive medicine, the evolution from prevention of communicable disease (e.g., through immunization and infection control) to non-communicable disease (e.g., through changes in lifestyles) has not kept pace with the epidemiological transition in the country. The preference for specialist and inpatient care, still considered to represent better quality medicine, generates a self-perpetuating system where the better medical students specialize, upward referral by primary caregivers is almost automatic, and diagnostic capacity is concentrated in hospitals, which get preference in allocation of investment and recurrent budgets. This penchant for specialization results in medical practice that is extremely fragmented and compartmentalized with little cross-referral among specialties and much duplication of services. This fragmentation leads to longer hospital stays and generally results in poor patient care. 1.19 Medical practice is dominated by a complex, inflexible, and often outdated set of norms and standards covering a broad range of items from the management of specific medical conditions to standards for the layout of rooms in hospitals. These norms and standards, which are strictly enforced by the MOH or the SCSES, serve as the principal mechanism for quality "control" (backed by a strict punitive system) leaving little room for professional judgement or accountability by individual practitioners, their peers or their managers. There is little evidence that costs or affordability have been factored into the norms and standards in application. 1.20 The ultimate result of the current culture of care is a highly cost-ineffective, unresponsive system unable to produce the maximum benefits possible from an already extremely limited resource envelope. D. HEALTH FINANCING Sources of Financing 1.21 The Russian health care system is largely publicly funded. Until 1992, the main sources of health financing were the federal budget and enterprises. Household expenditures for health were minimal, mainly going to purchase of drugs for outpatient services. In 1992, responsibility for health financing was decentralized to the oblasts. In 1993, a 3.6 percent payroll tax for compulsory health insurance was introduced. The payroll tax is collected by a Territorial Health Insurance Fund (THIF) at the oblast level which retains 3.4 percent, and remits 0.2 percent to the Federal Health Insurance Fund (FHIF) which is responsible for oversight and for providing equalization payments to economically disadvantaged oblasts. 1.22 Decentralization, the introduction of the payroll tax, and the entry of private insurers and providers have radically changed the pattern of financing for health. Although data on the private sector may not be completely accurate, it is estimated that private expenditures on health, by enterprises and households combined, constituted 18 percent of total health expenditures in 1994. In the same year, 71 percent of total government expenditures for health were financed out of local (oblast and rayon) budgets, and 18 percent out of THIF revenues. Only 10 percent of government health expenditures came from the federal budget.

REFORMS 1.31 In the late 1980s, dissatisfaction with the health system's performance led to a search for new ways to organize and manage care. Three oblasts - St. Petersburg, Kemerovo, and Samara - were the sites of experiments with a New Economic Mechanism that partially decentralized health care management and introduced new payment mechanisms. Instead of receiving budgets determined principally by input levels, health facilities were paid on the basis of performance. Polyclinics became "fundholders" responsible for managing a capitation-based allocation on behalf of the registered population, in return for which they would guarantee all necessary care. This was an encouragement to minimize unnecessary use of services and excessively high-cost care. Hospitals were reimbursed for treating patients according to the type and complexity of illness, classified into Clinical Statistical Groups (CSG), much like the DRG system in the United States. Although the system contained serious flaws, including the absence of quality assurance mechanisms to counteract the incentive to reduce service levels and the lack of a cap to contain total hospital costs, the experiment succeeded in reducing hospital admissions and length of stay, as well as bed capacity. 1.32 The series of laws and decrees passed from 1991 through 1993 brought sweeping changes to the health sector. They confirmed the new Government's intent to guarantee universal access to health services, created the framework for both mandatory and voluntary health insurance, introduced a 3.6
 Introduction Page 9 percent payroll tax paid by employers to fund mandatory health insurance, decentralized management and finance of health services, authorized the use of new provider payment mechanisms and gave individuals the right to choose an insurer. 1.33 There were great hopes on the part of its proponents that "insurance medicine," as it was called, would produce major improvements in Russian health care. In actual fact, the results of the recent changes have been disappointing, for a number of reasons. First, the system was adopted without sufficient preparation. Although the earlier experiments on provider payments taught valuable lessons, there had been no experience in the management of compulsory health insurance funds. Implementing regulations were insufficient and appropriate regulatory bodies did not exist. Private health insurance companies which were expected to be the principal insurers were initially few in numbers. Although hundreds of new companies emerged in just a few years, they were largely inexperienced. At the oblast level, the respective responsibilities and authorities of Oblast Health Authorities and THIFs were not clearly delineated. Neither the Federal Ministry of Health nor the FHIF were in a position to offer guidance to local authorities or to the newly constituted THIFs in implementing the law. 1.34 It is increasingly recognized that the process of reform will require years, even decades, to complete. In addition to filling the regulatory and institutional gaps in the health financing system, closer attention needs to be given to the service delivery system, to enable it to respond effectively to the new financing environment. System-wide as well as at the level of the facility and the individual practitioner, efficient and cost-effective organizational and managerial systems and clinical practices need to be introduced. The introduction of the practice of Family Medicine in 1992 was an important first step in restructuring the delivery system in favor of primary care, but much more is required. In the process of restructuring, massive investments will be needed to upgrade the quality of physical and human capital in the system to make up for years of under-investment, particularly at those levels of the system that promise to be the most cost-effective. 1.35 The current fluid state of governance in the health sector is one of the most difficult factors to contend with in undertaking health reform. The decentralization of health care, the introduction of compulsory health insurance and the entry of private insurers and providers have changed governance relationships fundamentally. The MOH has lost virtually all responsibility for management and financing of care. The oblasts, which have inherited this authority are eager to take charge of their health systems and make important policy decisions. However, given the limited access to information on alternative health systems and a lack of the necessary expertise at this level, oblast authorities are largely unprepared to do this. At the same time, there is clearly a need to maintain a basic regulatory framework for the entire Federation including both medical and financial aspects of health care, as well as to build leadership and guidance to facilitate reform in all 89 oblasts ("subjects of the Federation") and avoid wasteful duplication. This latter role, for which the MOH and other federal-level institutions are well- placed, requires a fundamental change in orientation and a new skills mix not yet found in these institutions. 1.36 As Russia proceeds with the difficult challenge of formulating and implementing strategies for health reform, the following areas of reform are expected to dominate: * The Regulatory Environment for Health Insurance. The legislative and regulatory framework needs to be modified and/or further developed. Still to be clarified are: the level of contributions to be made on behalf of the non-working population; the financial entitlement per capita, adjusted for risk, to be transferred to insurance companies on behalf of each insured; the minimum package of services guaranteed under the compulsory system. The
 Page 10 Introduction oversight and regulatory framework for HIFs and private insurance companies must be defined and the relevant regulatory agencies established. * Provider Payments. Problems with early experiments in new provider payment mechanisms are not surprising given the intricacies involved in crafting payment systems that try to meet often conflicting objectives: improving quality, capping costs, reducing reliance on high-tech medicine, motivating physicians, protecting consumers. Further experiments should be encouraged, with appropriate technical guidance. Ongoing experiments should be assessed and their findings widely disseminated. * Clinical Practices and Other Norms. Clinical practices must be brought up-to-date and made more cost-conscious across all fields of medicine. In particular, guidelines for managing different disease categories must give greater emphasis to preventive interventions, the role of the primary care provider, and outpatient diagnosis and treatment. High-tech, high-cost interventions must be evaluated with respect to both cost-effectiveness and affordability. Corresponding norms for staffing, technology and infrastructure requirements at all levels of the system must be adjusted as new clinical norms are developed. * Restructuring the Health Care Industry. Cost-effective health care delivery will require significant reorientation in the structure of the health services network, away from specialized inpatient facilities and in favor of outpatient facilities. The network of family physicians will form the foundation of outpatient services, supported by appropriate (affordable) diagnostic and referral services. Massive investments in retraining of health personnel as well as investments in physical capital to strengthen outpatient capacity are necessary. Downsizing of the hospital sector should proceed in parallel. * Autonomy of Health Providers. As a real market for health services emerges, with providers no longer unconditionally guaranteed their budgets and incomes, managers of health facilities and individual providers can be expected to absorb a larger share of autonomy as well as accountability. Health service institutions from hospitals down to the solo practitioner will need to function more like free-standing economic units, subject of course to appropriate regulations and financing arrangements. Stable financing sources and well-defined provider payment systems, complemented with modern quality assurance mechanisms, are prerequisites for provider autonomy. Professional associations also have a role to play, in re-education of practitioners and eventually in setting up self-policed quality assurance mechanisms. * Development of Public Institutions. Public institutions, including the Ministry of Health, the Sanitary Service, research and academic institutions, and oblast and local authorities will need to redefine their roles vis-a-vis provision, regulation and support of other health institutions. Among the key tasks of public institutions will be to provide political leadership in the drive to promote healthier lifestyles. Appropriate regulatory bodies to oversee operations of insurance companies and providers, as well as effective fora for negotiation between insurers and providers need to be established. Consumer interest groups should also be encouraged. Consumers must learn to exercise their rights and obligations and take greater responsibility for their own health.

Specifically, it would expand the role of primary care providers and shift most diagnostic procedures and about 30

To do this it would undertake a major restructuring of the delivery system. 3.6 Structure of the New System. The introduction of family physicians as the principal provider of primary care constitutes a central pillar of the restructuring. The family physician replaces the present cadre of "therapists" and shifts the emphasis away from medical specialization. At present the therapist is trained at a rudimentary level in the discipline of internal medicine but in practice does little more than screen patients for referral to specialists. Specialists tend to emphasize hospitalization and are trained to be technology dependent. In contrast, the family physician is trained to emphasize health promotion and prevention services and is able to treat the bulk of common ailments and injuries without the need for high technology. The family physician (together with medical assistants and nurses trained in family centered health care) will constitute the point of entry into the health system and function as "gatekeepers" for the system. Except in emergency cases, all admissions to higher levels of the system will require referral from primary care providers. The current practice of self-referral by patients directly to higher levels of the system will no longer be permitted. Family physicians will also increasingly receive patients who are referred back from higher levels of the system for follow-up care. 3.7 Family physicians in solo and small group practices (with three or fewer doctors) will be located in ambulatories where therapists are currently found as well as in existing smaller polyclinics or district hospitals. In higher density areas (e.g., in Kaluga city) family physicians will be organized into group practices consisting of four or more physicians. These group practices will offer the same services as family physicians, similarly acting as primary caregivers and gatekeepers. In the initial stages, group practices could consist of groups of sub-specialists (e.g., pediatricians, obstetrician-gynecologists, internists) offering primary care but without specialist training in family-oriented care. Over time, these same specialists could be trained to function as full-fledged family physicians, although with a particular strong field of practice related to their earlier specialization. Primary care group practices will be established at large polyclinics attached to rayon or municipal hospitals, in existing smaller polyclinics, or in a limited number of new facilities in Kaluga Municipality. 3.8 The family physician will have access to Consultation, Diagnostic and Treatment Centers (CDTC) to which referrals can be made on an outpatient basis. The CDTC would replace the polyclinic as the multi-disciplinary outpatient referral facility, providing services in about 15 medical disciplines. CDTCs will be endowed with diagnostic and treatment capacity greater than that currently found in polyclinics. This would allow them to carry out many more tests on an outpatient basis prior to or in lieu of hospitalization. They would also gradually develop capacity to offer day surgery. Polyclinics/CDTCs attached to rayon or municipal hospitals, at present administratively part of the hospital, will become independent functional units. They will, however, also provide diagnostic services to hospitals, reducing the need for maintaining duplicative diagnostic capacity in hospitals. In turn, day surgery centers in CDTCs will have access to surgical and related facilities in hospitals. 3.9 Inpatient capacity will be significantly reduced. District hospitals, most of which are too small to function efficiently, will be gradually closed or reorganized into nursing homes under the responsibility of other social services. In a few cases parts of the district hospitals will be transformed into general or group practices. In the larger hospitals, changes in the scope and capacity of outpatient services should lead to reductions in inpatient admissions as well as in length of stay. Organizational improvements within hospitals and upgrading of the physical capital would also reduce length of stay. 3.10 Oblast, municipal and rayon management teams will be constituted to provide guidance to health practitioners and facility managers during the period of transition.

Project Justification Project Concept 6.1 This project is built on the premise that health outcomes and client satisfaction can improve significantly in Russia, even with health expenditures remaining within current and expected resource constraints. These improvements could be attained through selective investments to renew the stock of physical and human capital in the system and through major restructuring of the health system in all its aspects - clinical, financial, organizational and managerial - in such a way as to use the available resources more efficiently. Experience has shown that a health system that favors prevention over cure, general (or primary) care over specialized care, and outpatient over inpatient care, performs more efficiently in the long run. This fundamental principle drives the investment choices that have been made in the project and shapes the reform that is being undertaken. Choice of Project Components 6.2 The project concentrates on three generic types of components: (i) changing provider incentives; (ii) restructuring the health care system in favor of outpatient care and Family Medicine; and (iii) improving clinical practices. The underlying strategic choice was to focus on systemic interventions that could trigger changes whose benefits would extend beyond the immediate reach of project investments and beyond the project lifetime. 6.3 Changing Provider Incentives. The new provider payment systems to be introduced under the project would aim to promote primary care, eliminate unnecessary referrals to specialists, reduce hospital admissions, and reduce lengths of stay in hospitals. This would be accomplished by changing current input-based payment methods to performance- or output-based methods. A fundholding system with the primary provider as fundholder - either for outpatient services only or for all services including hospital care - would encourage family physicians to offer as broad a range of services as possible and cut down unnecessary referrals to diagnostic facilities or to hospitals. Case-based hospital payment systems would reduce average length of stay and encourage overall efficiency. 6.4 Experiments in the late 1980s in Kemerovo Oblast and St. Petersburg showed that fundholding combined with case-based hospital payments successfully reduced hospital admissions and average length of stay, and allowed a reduction in the number of hospital beds. In Kemerovo, hospital admissions were ten percent lower in 1989 than in 1987. Bed capacity declined by 1,500 beds, with a substantial shift in structure of hospital units. In St. Petersburg, hospital admissions fell by five percent during the same period. About 2,500 beds became unnecessary, and some hospitals were restructured into nursing homes. The average length of stay fell from 19 to 17 days. Bed allocations by unit also changed. In the Kemerovo and St. Petersburg experiments, fundholding was done by the polyclinic (which included primary care providers and outpatient specialists), rather than the primary care provider. The present project would experiment with bringing fundholding one level further down in the system, hopefully encouraging further reductions in referrals. Case-based hospital payment schedules would also be refined to further encourage cost-effective case management. 6.5 An alternative payment mechanism for hospitals - global budgeting adjusted for case-mix, severity and volume of services - will also be tested under the project. This would combine the advantages of a global budgeting system that puts a direct cap on overall hospital costs with a
 Justification and Risks Page 53 performance-based system which encourages cost-effectiveness and efficiency. Applied in tandem with a fundholding system for outpatient care, this would prevent the potential loss of cost control often identified with a shift to performance-based payment systems. 6.6 Investments in institutional structures to strengthen quality assurance would help ensure that the quality of care is protected under the pressures of cost-cutting. New management information systems would support these QA systems as well as financial and other management requirements of payment reform and a restructured delivery system. 6.7 Restructuring the Delivery System. Quality of care in Russia cannot improve substantially unless physical and human capital are restored after years of neglect. Project investments in equipment, training and civil works would improve the effectiveness of care and, therefore, both outcomes and consumer satisfaction. Given limitations on available resources in the system, selectivity in the choice of investments is an essential feature of the project. Because these investments are concentrated on primary and secondary levels of care, they address a wider range of health needs and reach a larger share of the population than past investments which tended to favor specialist and inpatient services. The focus on Family Medicine is especially crucial to building a credible primary care system that could keep a larger number of clients at the lowest-cost end of the system, while still satisfying quality requirements. The concept of the Consultation, Diagnosis and Treatment Center (CDTC) as support to the primary provider would reinforce the latter's role. In addition, better-equipped (though not excessively sophisticated) CDTCs would keep patients out of hospitals as long as possible. Training of staff and managers of the concerned facilities will include not just new techniques related to new equipment, but also the new relations that need to exist among facilities and caregivers, and the corresponding flow of patients and flow of funds that should differ significantly from the current situation. Training for primary providers, combined with the new incentive system, will encourage a greater reliance on preventive measures. 6.8 Improving Clinical Practice. Clinical practices that are out-of-date and/or not cost-conscious are a critical systemic problem in Russia, cutting across all fields of medicine. Besides the direct benefit to the quality and effectiveness of specific services, the collective exercise of improving clinical practices in all fields is an essential step in designing restructured incentive systems, delivery networks, and many other components of health reform. The tasks of updating standards of clinical practice and undertaking the necessary investments in human and physical capital to retool the system accordingly are immense. They can only be accomplished over years or even decades. Maternal and Child Health (MCH) and Cardiovascular Disease (CVD) have been selected as illustrative cases for this exercise and it is hoped that the approach applied under the project to these two selected fields will stimulate similar initiatives in other fields of clinical practice. In this respect, project investments are justified not just for their direct effects on maternal, infant, or cardiovascular health, but also for their value in demonstrating approaches to changing clinical practice. 6.9 The choice of MCH and CVD was the result of informed judgement that took into account a variety of factors: the overall burden of disease; the scope for improving current clinical approaches; the potential costs of these improvements per Disability-Adjusted Life-Year (DALY) saved; the potential for packaging groups of relatively cost-effective interventions in a shared delivery mechanisms (as with reproductive health services for women); and the opportunity to establish patterns of change that could transfer to other areas of care (especially the shift of emphasis to preventive measures, the stress on basic emergency services, and the limited use of high-tech equipment or interventions).

Rationale for Public Sector Involvement 6.12 Imperfections and failures in the health care market (externalities, uncertainty, asymmetry of information, market power) as well as societal equity considerations are arguments used to justify public sector involvement in health care. The form of involvement by the public sector differs among countries - with varying degrees of involvement in financing, provision and regulation - and there is not always clear evidence for preferring one form over another. In most cases, the historical context out of which the contemporary system evolved plays a dominant role in determining reform priorities and possibilities. But there is growing convergence towards certain models that have proven more robust than others. 6.13 Public financing of health care is primarily motivated by equity considerations. Russia has made the choice to continue funding health through government budgets and an earmarked payroll tax, and through these sources, to guarantee universal access to a certain standard of care. The significance of this social/political choice cannot be underestimated. Although the Soviet system was noted for its wide geographic access, rationing did take place particularly at the higher end of the system where "informal" cash payments tended to be larger and where one's place on the queue was determined by one's connections. A public guarantee of universal access under a new economic regime that tends to widen economic inequality would represent a major pillar in any new system of social protection. In making the choice for public financing the public sector also takes on responsibility for ensuring that these funds are used cost-effectively and that the costs of guaranteed entitlements are sustainable within fiscal limits and within limits set on the payroll tax burden. Provider-payment mechanisms, if appropriately designed, are potent tools to accomplish both the equity and efficiency objectives of public financing. In Russia, provider payment is particularly important because of the lack of financial and other incentives for efficiency and accountability under the old Soviet system. 6.14 Many personal health services can be provided efficiently by the private sector once an appropriate incentive structure and regulatory framework are in place. The Russian Government has taken the first steps in the long road to privatization by separating the functions of financing and provision within the health care system, introducing elements of competition into the market (e.g., choice of provider and insurance company) and decentralizing certain budget decisions to the level of the facility. In order for providers to function as fully independent economic units, further reforms are required to stabilize the new financing sources, clarify provider payment rules, develop accountability and managerial skills among providers, and create the appropriate regulatory framework for both the health insurance industry and providers. Reforms supported by the project would further these goals. Beyond these changes, and outside the scope of the present project, mechanisms for transferring ownership of facilities
 Page 56 Justification and Risks from the public to the private sector (or transferring responsibility for asset management and financing to the semi-public sector, as in the case of the self-governing Hospital Trusts in the UK) will eventually need to be developed. 6.15 Finally, although provision of public health services are often considered the domain of the public sector, this project introduces an approach to the funding of health promotion activities - through the establishment of health promotion funds for MCH and CVD - that opens the possibility for sub- contracting such activities to the private sector. Focus on the Oblast 6.16 The choice of the oblast as the focus of the project was both strategic and opportunistic. The initial focus of project preparation was a set of nine priority programs organized under the initiative of the MOH, with each effectively approached as a vertical program under separate leadership within the federal structure. However, within a few months of preparation, it became evident that decentralization of financing and management of care to the oblasts had shifted the locus of reform from the federal to the local level. In addition, while federal institutions like the MOH struggled to redefine their new roles (especially with the MOH having lost responsibility for service delivery but gained new responsibility for medical industries), oblast authorities had no choice but to continue services under highly unstable circumstances and were hence more receptive to reform. 6.17 The choice to work with the oblasts having been made, a number of high-priority issues are wholly or largely excluded from this project because they require significant intervention at the federal level. Among them are: regulation of the health insurance industry; development of federal level institutions; financing, distribution and use of pharmaceuticals; and multi-sectoral public health programs. They would, however, be high priority choices for future Bank funding. Choice of Pilot Approach 6.18 Almost every intervention in the project involves a change in the way of doing business in the health sector. Although studiously drawn from successful experience in other countries, and carefully adapted to local conditions, there is little real-world experience to judge how they would turn out when actually applied in Russia. In addition to uncertainties about implementation feasibility and expected effectiveness, there is little real-world (i.e., in Russia) basis for predicting the costs or sustainability of the interventions proposed. Best efforts have been made to estimate recurrent costs of the new outpatient- based system to be introduced in Kaluga, using common international standards (para 6.24), and assumptions are made about how providers will change behavior in response to new incentives. However, these assumptions need to be verified by actual experience. Hence the choice of the pilot approach. 6.19 The project also tests an approach to health reform that is centered on local-level authorities. The experience of two oblasts managing broad-ranging reform, and the types of support required to help them accomplish their objectives, should provide valuable lessons that could be replicated in other parts of the country. The two national-level components in the project - the National Family Medicine Program and the Monitoring, Evaluation and Dissemination Component - demonstrate ways in which assistance from federal level institutions can help enhance the oblasts' chances of success, and hopefully would lead to a better definition of roles for federal-level institutions in the decentralized system.

At the oblast level: (a) better quality health services, greater consumer satisfaction, and improvements in health outcomes both during and after the project for the populations of Kaluga and Tver; (b) more stable and transparent mechanism for public financing of services to improve equity of access especially at the primary and secondary levels of care; (c) more cost-effective health care systems able to produce better outcomes at current and expected resource levels; and (d) stronger, more efficient health institutions, including individual health facilities, Oblast Health Authorities, and Territorial Health Insurance Funds. Sustainability and Fiscal Impact of the Project 6.23 The sustainability of health services in Russia is a central focus of the Project. Output-driven incentive systems (with built-in caps to contain overall costs), outpatient-oriented care, and more efficient and cost-conscious clinical practices all aim at defining a publicly-guaranteed package of services that is affordable in the long run. However, while the restructuring from inpatient to outpatient care or from ineffective to more cost-effective clinical practices takes place, the health system will go through a transitional period of increased recurrent cost requirements. These increased costs result because: (i) outpatient services must expand in range and improve in quality to replace inpatient care; (ii) badly- needed quality improvements in inpatient services will involve higher recurrent costs and (iii) the fixed costs of inpatient services are high and reductions in bed-days do not easily convert into full potential savings until corresponding facility closings and staff retrenchment can take place.

Additional information on the oblasts can be found in the project files. Background 2. Both Kaluga and Tver oblasts are located in Central Russia, within 200 kilometers of Moscow. The capital city of each oblast has a long history, dating to the Middle Ages. Kaluga oblast covers 29,900 square kilometers, and had a population of approximately 1,085,000 in 1994. Tver is the largest oblast in central Russia, with a low population density. Almost 75 percent of the citizens of Kaluga and Tver reside in what are considered urban areas, with a large number living in the capital city (33 percent, or 360,400 in Kaluga city; 28 percent, or 470,000 in Tver city). 3. These oblasts have seen significant population decreases in recent years, steeper than that in Russia as a whole, through a combination of steeply falling birth rates and slightly rising death rates. As a result, the populations of both oblasts are aging. In 1994 the crude birth rate was 8.2 per 1,000 population in Kaluga and the crude death rate 17.4 per 1,000 population. About 20 percent of the oblast's population is over age 60. Prior to World War II, Tver Oblast reached its peak population of 2,900,000, about 75 percent larger than today. Overall, about 18.7% of the population is over age 60, with an even higher proportion of aged (28.9%) in rural areas. In 1994 the birth rate had fallen to 7.7 per 1,000 population, the lowest level since World War Two. The death rate in 1994 was 21.0 per 1,000. Socioeconomic Situation 4. Although Kaluga and Tver share similar geographic and demographic characteristics, their economic base varies. The economy of Kaluga oblast, especially before the break-up of the Soviet Union, was dominated by the military-industrial complex. Kaluga was one of the centers of rocket technology as well as a center for the production of engines for military use. The dominant sector is industry, which employs 34 percent of the working population. The major industrial products are engines, turbines, electronics and railway machinery. The social sector places second, with 20 percent of the work force, while agriculture accounts for 13 percent of employment. 5. Tver's economy has been built on trade, timber, textiles, cattle, and heavy manufacturing. In addition to lumber, much of Tver's timber has been used to produce pulp paper, with a prominent parallel industry emerging in printing and publishing. Beef and dairy cattle, as well as hog and chicken production, continue to be important products. Tver has a national reputation for its linen and cotton fabrics. For over 100 years, Tver has manufactured over half of all the railroad cars used in Russia. Glass products, for both industrial and home use, are also produced here. 6. The economies of both regions have been hard hit by the break-up of the Soviet Union. Several key industries in Tver oblast, especially textiles and manufacturing, have been dependent on historical trade links with other geographic regions now considered independent states. In Kaluga oblast, many industrial enterprises and military industries have slowed or stopped production. In both regions, high inflation and the scarcity and high cost of consumer goods, including food and energy, has undermined the economy of most families. Unemployment is on the rise and an increasing number of people are living below the official poverty line.

As can be seen in Table 1, the health status of the populations of Kaluga and Tver reflects many of the same characteristics found throughout Russia, and especially Central Russia. Both regions have suffered deteriorating health status for some years. 8. Among adults, mortality from major chronic non-communicable diseases has increased considerably, particularly cardiovascular diseases, and cancers. In addition, accidents and trauma have increased dramatically. Underlying reasons for these increased mortality rates include three major factors. First, unhealthy lifestyles, including diets high in fat, smoking, alcohol consumption increase rates of chronic disease. Second, high levels of stress associated with the social and economic transition influence both health status and accident rates. Third, the deterioration in the quality of health care services and the shortage of financing limit the ability to respond to these problems. 9. The health status of pregnant women and their infants is somewhat better in Kaluga than Tver, although it is low in both oblasts when compared to other industrialized countries. In 1994, infant mortality was 17.1 per 1,000 live births in Kaluga, a rate two times higher than in the countries of Europe and North America. The corresponding figure for Tver was 19.5 per 1,000. In both oblasts, abortion remains the primary means of fertility regulation, with almost two abortions for every live birth. According to official statistics, only about one in five women in these regions use modern forms of contraception (19.3 percent in Kaluga and 23 percent in Tver). Repeat abortion is a potential cause of infertility; abortion is also responsible for at least 25 percent of maternal deaths nationwide. A trend toward increasing incidence of sexually transmitted infections also jeopardizes both reproductive health and infant health. Health Services 10. Following the Russian pattern, both oblasts have a number of specialty and referral hospitals under the direction of the Oblast Health Authority, with local authorities responsible for district hospitals, village dispensaries, and feldsher stations. As a general rule, oblast and lower level institutions consist of both a hospital and polyclinic, under the joint direction of the head doctor. In addition, in both Tver and Kaluga, additional facilities are operated independently by the federal ministries of railroads, defense, nuclear energy, and by some industrial enterprises. 11. There are 12,500 hospital beds in Kaluga oblast, or about 115 beds for every 10,000 people. The distribution of beds includes 5,100 beds in rayon and district hospitals; 1,280 at the Central Oblast Hospital; 2,765 in oblast specialist institutions; 2,500 beds in Kaluga municipality; 780 beds in sanitariums and 75 beds for nursing care. The ratio of acute beds to population is about 110 beds per 10,000 - notably higher than ratios of 45 to 70 beds per 10,000 common in Europe and America, although slightly lower than in Kaluga. 12. The average length of stay in Kaluga oblast is 18.5 days, although it varies by specialty. In Tver, the average hospital stay is in excess of 15 days. An additional period of recuperation in a sanitarium follows most hospitalizations. As elsewhere in Russia, the financing of health services in Kaluga and Tver is complex and dynamic. Historically, health services have been provided to the population free of charge. Prior to the break- up of the Soviet Union, they were financed through allocations from the federal government. With the decentralization of responsibility for health care to the oblast and local levels (beginning in the late 1980s), both financing and allocation of resources for the vast majority of health services are local responsibilities. Kaluga and Tver have both begun implementing the compulsory health insurance scheme mandated by the federal government in 1991. The THIF reimburses hospitals on the basis of finished cases and polyclinics on a per visit basis. In all facilities, doctors are salaried employees. A number of innovative provider reimbursement arrangements have begun in Tver. The rayon hospital in Vishniy Volochok, for example, has signed a contract with the THIF that includes incentives to economize: the hospital may retain any payments it receives in excess of costs (up to 20 percent variance) if its patients are discharged earlier than the prescribed norms. doc.repnme: Russian Federation - Health Reform Pilot Project
doc.abstracts: The Health Reform Pilot Project's objective is to achieve improvements in the quality and efficiency of health care and in reproductive and cardiovascular health outcomes in two pilot oblasts sufficient to make decisions about national adoption of specific health reform measures. The project consists of four parts: two independent sub-projects, each consisting of a package of reform measures to be undertaken in a participating oblast; one component to strengthen national and regional training programs in Family Medicine; and one component to monitor, evaluate, disseminate and replicate project results. Although the underlying principles of reform are the same, each oblast sub-project is unique, having been shaped by local oblast priorities, institutional capacities, and other local conditions.
